metadata.description:
The data sets include four sets of data obtained from the Scanning Multi-channel Microwave Radiometer (SMMR), Special Sensor Microwave Imager (SSM/I) and the Special Sensor Microwave Imager Sounder (SSMIS) sensors using passive microwave remote sensing inversion. SMMR was aboard the Nimbus-7 satellite, and its working period was from October 26, 1978 to July 8, 1987. Since July 1987, the data provided by the SSM/I and the SSMIS aboard the US Defense Meteorological Satellite Program (DMSP) satellite group have been used.

The first three data sets contain sea ice concentration data, covering the Antarctic region with a spatial resolution of 25 km:
(1) The data were obtained from Nimbus-7 SMMR and DMSP SSM/I-SSMIS Version 1 by applying the NASA Team algorithm inversion. The temporal coverage is from November 1978 to February 2017, with a temporal resolution of one month. A bin file is stored every month.
(2) The data source is the same as the first set. The temporal coverage is from 1978-10-26 to 2017-2-28. The temporal resolution is two days, and the spatial resolution is 25 km. A folder was stored every year, and a bin file was stored every other day.
(3) The data were obtained from near-real-time DMSP SSMIS by applying the NASA Team algorithm inversion. The temporal coverage is from 2015-1-1 to 2018-2-3, and the temporal resolution is one day. A bin file is stored every day. Each file consists of a 300-byte file title (data time information, projection pattern, file name) and a 316*332 matrix.

The fourth set of data is the sea ice coverage and sea ice area time series. The temporal coverage is from November 1978 to December 2017. This data set is a time series sequence of sea ice coverage and sea ice area in the Antarctic. The temporal resolution is one month, and an ASCII file is stored every month. Each file consists of a file title (time, data type), a 39*1 sea ice cover matrix and a 39*1 sea ice area matrix.
For further details on the data, please visit the US Ice and Snow Data Center NSIDC website - Data Description http://nsidc.org/data/NSIDC-0051; http://nsidc.org/data/NSIDC-0081; http://nsidc.org/data/G02135

background: The Arctic has experienced extensive sea ice retreat in recent decades, as observed from satellite remote sensing and simulated by general circulation models. The significant low albedo of melt pond compared with snow and ice results in more absorption of radiation compared with sea ice without melt pond, which will then enhance sea ice melt to form more melt pond. This so-called positive feedback of melt pond is crucial for sea ice thermal and physical properties. The quantification of melt pond coverage is important for the energy balance and climate change studies of the Earth. Recent studies show that the considering of melt pond in sea ice model can improve the prediction skill of sea ice models. Satellite derived melt pond cover fraction also served as calibration and validation dataset for sea ice process models. The assimilation of satellite derived melt pond cover fraction in sea ice model also has the potential to improve the sea ice modeling. These studies indicate that the melt pond related process is important in the ocean and sea ice system. The melt pond coverage varies significantly spatially and temporally, satellite remote sensing provides a possible solution in determining the spatial coverage of melt pond.
research objective: This work aims to develop a new physically based algorithm for retrieving the cover fraction of melt ponds on sea ice using remote sensing data.
challenges: All the above-mentioned melt pond cover fraction estimation methods based on active or passive microwave remote sensing suffer from the fundamental shortcoming of the similar microwave scattering and emission signature of melt pond and open water. The varying sea ice microwave signature, distinct microwave scattering and emission signature of dry snow/ice and wet snow/ice, and varying water surface roughness also makes the melt pond cover fraction retrieval from active and passive microwave remote sensing challenging. The constant endmember reflectance (snow, ice, melt pond, and open water) assumption may cause deviation of estimated MPF from real values, because the reflectance of melt pond varies spatially and temporally with underlying sea ice and melt pond parameters. However, the quality of machine learning algorithms depends on the training samples. The limited training data used in training may cause region and time dependent error in estimating MPF because of the spatial and temporal variation of sea ice and melt pond reflectance. Currently the quantity of training data is not enough to develop a robust machine learning based MPF retrieval algorithm.
methods: In the newly developed algorithm, dynamic sea ice and melt pond reflectances are used in the pixel spectral unmixing for melt pond fraction (MPF) estimation. Radiative transfer models for sea ice and melt pond reflectance modeling are developed for MPF retrieval algorithm. The validation of retrieved MPF and its comparison with static pixel spectral unmixing results show that the dynamic algorithm proposed in this study has the potential of application in wide range of situations by considering dynamic spectral reflectances of melt pond and sea ice. First, a melt pond reflectance model and sea ice reflectance model are developed based on Mie scattering theory and multiple layer radiative transfer theory. In the MPF estimation algorithm developed in this study, linear pixel unmixing algorithm is used such as used in many studies, but with dynamic endmember reflectance. A special index and melt pond depth are used to describe the melt pond reflectance, and then look up table (LUT) is constructed in the MPF estimation algorithm when searching for optimized spectral reflectance. Then, 22-year Pan-Arctic MPF is produced using the newly develop algorithm and the spatial – temporal characteristics of MPF in Arctic is analyzed and discussed.
dataset: Atmospheric corrected MODIS Surface Reflectance 8-Day L3 version 6 (MOD09A1) is used to estimate the MPF in this study. The spatial resolution of the MOD09A1 product is 500 m, and the temporal resolution is 8 days. In this study, the remote sensing retrieved MPF in Arctic is validated using three independent sets of in-situ data. MEDEA (National Technical Means images): This dataset is generated based on high-resolution optical satellite images by Webster et al. (2015) and contains two independent data sets, one is obtained by Webster et al. (2015), covering the period from 1999 to 2014, and the other is obtained by using supervised classification techniques, covering the period from 1999 to 2001. WorldView(WV): WorldView-2 provides commercial panchromatic images with a resolution of 0.46 m and eight-band multispectral images with a resolution of 1.84 m. The MPF used in this study is derived using WorldView satellite images by Wright and Polashenski (2019) during 2010 – 2015, and the data covers the period from March to August of 2010 – 2015. NSIDC (National Snow and Ice Data Center): The high-resolution satellite images in this data set were obtained from four sites (Beaufort Sea, East Siberian Sea, Canadian Arctic and Fram Strait) located in the Arctic Ocean in 1999, 2000 and 2001. NPI (Norwegian Polar Institute): This dataset is derived from images acquired by a helicopter-borne camera. The footprint size of each data record is about 40 × 60 m. The images are taken during a field campaign on Arctic sea ice in summer 2012. TransArc: In this dataset the sea ice parameters are estimated visually during the Germany trans-Polar cruise ARKXXVI/3 during August to September 2011. IceWatch: This dataset is from the IceWatch community which co-ordinates visual observation of sea ice conducted from ships. The sea ice and melt pond cover fraction are also estimated visually from the bridge of ship. Data records from 2008 to 2020 are used in this study.
findings: The validation of retrieved MPF and its comparison with static pixel spectral unmixing results show that the dynamic algorithm proposed in this study has the potential of application in wide range of situations by considering dynamic spectral reflectances of melt pond and sea ice. Time series trend analysis of MPF in 2000 – 2021 reveals the significant increasing trend of relative MPF in the Arctic. The melt pond expansion in 2000 – 2021 is more obvious in the marginal areas, especially the marginal areas close to Russia coast. Trend analysis for typical regions such as Beaufort Sea, Greenland Sea, the Baffin Bay, Chukchi, East Siberian, Laptev, and Kara seas and center Arctic also reveals that the relative MPF and SIF show contrasting trend.

Concept Completion.Answer: SMMR, SSM/I, SSMIS, MODIS Surface Reflectance, WorldView, NSIDC, NPI

Concept Completion.Answer: similar microwave scattering and emission signatures of melt ponds and open water

Feature Specification.Answer: 25 km spatial resolution, daily to monthly temporal resolution, SMMR, SSM/I, SSMIS sensors, NASA Team algorithm

Feature Specification.Question: What specific attributes are considered when developing an algorithm for retrieving melt pond cover fraction using remote sensing data?
Feature Specification.Answer: dynamic sea ice reflectances, melt pond reflectances, spectral unmixing techniques, look-up tables for optimized spectral reflectance, spatial variability, temporal variability

Feature Specification.Answer: similar microwave scattering and emission signatures of melt ponds and open water, varying sea ice microwave signatures, differing reflectance of dry and wet snow/ice, assumption of constant endmember reflectance, limited training data, region and time-dependent errors

Quantification.Question: What is the temporal resolution of the near-real-time dataset for sea ice concentration in the Antarctic region?

Definition.Question: What does 'passive microwave remote sensing' mean in the context of sea ice data collection?
Definition.Answer: Passive microwave remote sensing refers to a method of collecting data where sensors detect naturally emitted microwave radiation from Earth's surface. In the context of sea ice data collection, it involves using sensors like SMMR, SSM/I, and SSMIS to capture microwave signals that provide information about sea ice characteristics such as concentration and extent without emitting any radiation themselves.

Definition.Question: What is a 'dynamic pixel spectral unmixing algorithm' in the context of remote sensing data analysis?
Definition.Answer: A dynamic pixel spectral unmixing algorithm is a method used in remote sensing to estimate the cover fraction of different surface types within a pixel by using variable spectral reflectance values. In the context of sea ice studies, it involves modeling the reflectance of melt ponds and sea ice dynamically to improve the accuracy of melt pond fraction estimation, as opposed to using static reflectance values, thereby accounting for spatial and temporal variations.

Comparison.Question: How does the use of passive microwave remote sensing for sea ice density estimation compare to the use of optical satellite images for melt pond cover fraction retrieval in terms of data collection challenges?
Comparison.Answer: Passive microwave remote sensing for sea ice density estimation faces challenges due to similar microwave scattering and emission signatures between melt ponds and open water, as well as varying sea ice microwave signatures. Optical satellite images for melt pond cover fraction retrieval also face challenges, such as the spatial and temporal variation of melt pond reflectance, which affects the accuracy of machine learning algorithms used for estimation.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges arise when using remote sensing data for estimating melt pond cover fractions on sea ice, and how can these be addressed through algorithm development?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in using remote sensing data for estimating melt pond cover fractions include the similar microwave scattering and emission signature of melt ponds and open water, as well as varying sea ice signatures. Additionally, the limited training data can cause errors due to spatial and temporal variations. These challenges can be addressed by developing algorithms that incorporate dynamic spectral reflectances of melt ponds and sea ice, using radiative transfer models for accurate reflectance modeling, and employing a linear pixel unmixing algorithm with dynamic endmember reflectance.

Interpretation.Question: What are the implications of observed trends in melt pond coverage for understanding sea ice and climate interactions, and how can data collection methods be improved to capture these dynamics more accurately?
Interpretation.Answer: Observed trends in melt pond coverage, such as the significant increasing trend of relative melt pond fraction in the Arctic and its expansion especially in marginal areas, have implications for understanding sea ice and climate interactions. These trends suggest changes in energy balance and feedback processes affecting sea ice melt. To capture these dynamics more accurately, data collection methods can be improved by increasing the quantity and quality of training data, utilizing dynamic spectral reflectance models, and enhancing the spatial and temporal resolution of remote sensing data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges of retrieving melt pond cover fraction from remote sensing data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in retrieving melt pond cover fraction from remote sensing data arise due to the similar microwave scattering and emission signatures of melt ponds and open water, varying sea ice microwave signatures, distinct scattering and emission signatures of dry and wet snow/ice, and varying water surface roughness. Additionally, the constant endmember reflectance assumption can cause deviations in estimates, while limited training data for machine learning algorithms can lead to region and time-dependent errors.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is dynamic spectral reflectance considered important in the algorithm for estimating melt pond fraction?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Dynamic spectral reflectance is important in the algorithm for estimating melt pond fraction because it accounts for the spatial and temporal variations in the reflectance of melt ponds and underlying sea ice, which enhances the accuracy and applicability of the retrieval algorithm across different situations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the limited availability of training data for developing machine learning algorithms in sea ice and melt pond analysis?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The limited availability of training data for developing machine learning algorithms in sea ice and melt pond analysis is caused by the spatial and temporal variation in the reflectance of sea ice and melt ponds, which makes it challenging to gather sufficient, diverse, and representative training samples needed to develop robust algorithms.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of using dynamic spectral reflectances in sea ice and melt pond data collection methods, compared to static pixel spectral unmixing techniques?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of dynamic spectral reflectances in data collection methods allows for the consideration of varying spectral properties of melt ponds and sea ice, enhancing the accuracy and applicability of the retrieval algorithm across different situations. It also improves the potential for accurate melt pond fraction estimation, leading to a more precise understanding of spatial-temporal characteristics in the Arctic.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the inclusion of satellite-derived melt pond cover fraction data influence the development and accuracy of sea ice models?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The inclusion of satellite-derived melt pond cover fraction data can improve the calibration and validation of sea ice models, enhancing their prediction skills. It also allows the assimilation of this data into models, potentially leading to more accurate simulations of sea ice processes and dynamics, which are critical for studying energy balance and climate change.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the anticipated challenges in estimating the melt pond cover fraction using active and passive microwave remote sensing, and what impact might these challenges have on data accuracy?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Challenges include the similar microwave scattering and emission signatures of melt ponds and open water, as well as varying microwave signatures of sea ice. These issues can lead to deviations in estimated melt pond fraction from real values, impacting the accuracy of the data. Additionally, the limited availability of training data for machine learning algorithms can introduce region and time-dependent errors in the estimation process.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of developing a new algorithm for retrieving melt pond cover fractions on sea ice using remote sensing data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to develop a new physically based algorithm that addresses the challenges of accurately estimating melt pond cover fractions due to the similar microwave scattering and emission signatures of melt ponds and open water. This algorithm aims to improve the estimation of melt pond coverage, which is crucial for understanding energy balance and climate change impacts.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to consider dynamic spectral reflectances in the development of algorithms for estimating melt pond fractions on sea ice?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Considering dynamic spectral reflectances is important because it allows the algorithm to account for spatial and temporal variations in the reflectance of melt ponds and sea ice. This improves the accuracy and applicability of the melt pond fraction estimation across different regions and time periods, addressing the limitations of constant endmember reflectance assumptions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in retrieving melt pond cover fraction from remote sensing data using a physically based algorithm?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In the newly developed algorithm, dynamic sea ice and melt pond reflectances are used in the pixel spectral unmixing for melt pond fraction (MPF) estimation. Radiative transfer models for sea ice and melt pond reflectance modeling are developed for MPF retrieval. The process involves using a melt pond reflectance model and a sea ice reflectance model based on Mie scattering theory and multiple layer radiative transfer theory. A linear pixel unmixing algorithm with dynamic endmember reflectance is applied, and a look-up table (LUT) is constructed to optimize spectral reflectance.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What challenges are encountered in estimating melt pond cover fraction from active or passive microwave remote sensing, and how might these be addressed?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Challenges include the similar microwave scattering and emission signature of melt ponds and open water, varying sea ice microwave signature, distinct scattering and emission signatures of dry and wet snow/ice, and varying water surface roughness. These factors make retrievals challenging. The constant endmember reflectance assumption can cause deviations, and limited training data can lead to region and time-dependent errors. Addressing these challenges involves using dynamic endmember reflectance and increasing the quantity and quality of training data for machine learning algorithms.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the accurate retrieval of melt pond cover fraction using remote sensing data?
Enablement.Answer: The development of a new physically based algorithm for retrieving the cover fraction of melt ponds on sea ice using remote sensing data has enabled more accurate retrieval. This involves the use of dynamic sea ice and melt pond reflectances in pixel spectral unmixing, and the development of radiative transfer models for sea ice and melt pond reflectance modeling.

Enablement.Question: What conditions facilitate the validation of remote sensing data for melt pond coverage in the Arctic region?
Enablement.Answer: Validation of remote sensing data for melt pond coverage is facilitated by using multiple independent in-situ datasets, such as high-resolution optical satellite images, helicopter-borne camera images, and visual observations from ship-based campaigns. These datasets provide ground truth against which remote sensing estimates can be compared.

Expectation.Question: Why might the dynamic spectral reflectance approach be expected to improve the accuracy of sea ice and melt pond fraction estimation in remote sensing data?
Expectation.Answer: The dynamic spectral reflectance approach accounts for the spatial and temporal variations in the reflectance properties of sea ice and melt ponds, providing a more accurate representation of the actual conditions. This method reduces the deviation caused by static reflectance assumptions, potentially leading to more accurate melt pond fraction estimations.

Expectation.Question: What challenges are anticipated in using machine learning algorithms for estimating melt pond fraction from remote sensing data, and how might these affect expected outcomes?
Expectation.Answer: Machine learning algorithms for estimating melt pond fraction face challenges due to limited training data, which can lead to region and time-dependent errors. The spatial and temporal variation in sea ice and melt pond reflectance, along with the similar scattering and emission signatures of melt ponds and open water, further complicate the estimation, affecting the expected accuracy and reliability of the results.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the effectiveness of using passive microwave remote sensing data for estimating sea ice melt pond coverage?
Judgmental.Answer: Passive microwave remote sensing data is a commonly used method for estimating sea ice melt pond coverage, but it faces challenges such as the similar microwave scattering and emission signatures of melt ponds and open water. Additionally, the dynamic nature of sea ice and varying signatures complicate the retrieval process. Despite these challenges, dynamic algorithms that consider spectral variations have shown potential in improving estimation accuracy.

Judgmental.Question: How would you assess the adequacy of current training data for developing robust machine learning algorithms in sea ice analysis?
Judgmental.Answer: The current training data for developing robust machine learning algorithms in sea ice analysis is considered limited. The spatial and temporal variations of sea ice and melt pond reflectance can lead to region and time-dependent errors. Therefore, the quantity and diversity of training data are not yet sufficient to develop highly reliable machine learning models for melt pond fraction retrieval.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data collection methods can accurately differentiate between melt ponds and open water using remote sensing techniques.
Assertion.Answer: The challenge in differentiating melt ponds from open water using remote sensing is due to their similar microwave scattering and emission signatures. Methods must account for varying sea ice microwave signatures and the distinct scattering and emission signatures of dry and wet snow/ice. The use of dynamic spectral reflectances and radiative transfer models can improve accuracy by considering the spatial and temporal variations in melt pond and sea ice reflectance.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how researchers address the limitation of machine learning algorithms in estimating melt pond coverage due to scarce training data.
Assertion.Answer: The limitation is addressed by developing a new algorithm that utilizes dynamic sea ice and melt pond reflectances for pixel spectral unmixing. The algorithm incorporates radiative transfer models and a look-up table for optimized spectral reflectance, which helps in mitigating the impact of limited training data by considering spatial and temporal variations.

Request/Directive.Question: Please provide an analysis of the challenges faced in retrieving melt pond cover fraction from passive microwave remote sensing data in polar regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in retrieving melt pond cover fraction from passive microwave remote sensing data include the similar microwave scattering and emission signature of melt ponds and open water, varying sea ice microwave signature, and the distinct scattering and emission signatures of dry and wet snow/ice. Additionally, the constant endmember reflectance assumption can cause deviations in estimated values due to spatial and temporal variations in reflectance. Limited training data for machine learning algorithms also results in region and time-dependent errors.
